data.title: OWNERS AND BREEDERS OF THE SEVENTEENTH AND EIGHTEENTH CENTURIES
data.text:
THE CREATORS OF THE THOROUGHBRED RACEHORSE

The racing of Running Horses for the purposes of gambling had long been established in England by the time it was banned, along with theatres, dancing and Christmas festivities, by Oliver Cromwell's Commonwealth. The Restoration of Charles II in 1660 saw the resumption of horse racing and the beginning of a breeding process that resulted in the production of the Thoroughbred Racehorse.

There is much confusion surrounding the identities, dates and pedigrees of the horses of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. The absence of names and dates for most of the mares, the custom of referring to imported oriental stallions by the names of their successive owners, horses known by more than one name and horses with identical names, has left us with a mass of unreliable, contradictory and sometimes downright impossible pedigrees.

In order to identify and date the horses of this period it is essential to know the owners and breeders of this period. They were members of the royal family, the nobility and the landed gentry, of well documented family histories, interrelated and were, with very few exceptions, descendants of, or married to descendants of, Henry I.

The Compiler of this website is JAMES RONALD HARDIMAN See below

See THE ANCESTORS OF JAMES RONALD HARDIMAN
